front.title: Best Current Practices for Securing Internet of Things (IoT) Devices

abstract.t: Vendors of embedded devices have started to connect their devices to the Internet and the weak security of those devices has been a challenge for the Internet infrastructure. This document lists a number of minimum requirements vendors of Internet of Things (IoT) devices need to take into account before selling those devices to avoid security problems or, in case of security incidents, to have ways to mitigate them.

section.title: Introduction
section.t: The weak security of Internet of Things devices has resulted in many press releases over the last few years and unfortunately very few lessons have been learned from those incidents. The rate at which IoT devices get compromised is increasing and the event of distributed denial of service attacks illustrated that not only users of IoT devices and their data is at risk but also the wider Internet infrastructure itself. This document aims to recommend a small number of minimum security requirements to avoid security problems.

The scope of these recommendations is as follows:
These measures described in this document are intended to impede network-based attacks. Other kinds of attacks, e.g. those requiring physical access to the device, are generally not considered in these requirements. The requirements do, however, reduce the implications of such physical attacks.
In principle these requirements apply to all hosts that connect to the Internet, but this list of requirements is specifically targeted at devices that are constrained in their capabilities, more than general-purpose programmable hosts (PCs, servers, laptops, tablets, etc.), routers, middleboxes, etc. While this is a fuzzy boundary it reflects the current understanding of IoT. A more detailed treatment of some of the constraints of IoT devices can be found in [[RFC of LWIG terminology]].
These are MINIMUM requirements that apply to all devices. They are unlikely to be sufficient by themselves, to ensure security of hosts from attack. Because IoT devices are used in a large number of different domains with different needs device will have its own unique security considerations. It is not feasible to completely list all security requirements in a document such as this. Vendors will have to do their threat assessment to determine which additional security considerations are applicable for use in a given application domain.
It is expected that this list of requirements will be revised from time to time as new threats are identified and/or new security techniques become feasible.
A companion document may be produced with suggestions for design choices and implementations that may aid in meeting these requirements. This document does not make recommendations for solutions.

We expect that many of the requirements can easily be met by the largest majority of vendors but may require additional documentation and transparency of those practices to improve crediability of their security practices in the market place.

section.title: Terminology
section.t: The key words “MUST”, “MUST NOT”, “REQUIRED”, “SHALL”, “SHALL NOT”, “SHOULD”, “SHOULD NOT”, “RECOMMENDED”, “NOT RECOMMENDED”, “MAY”, and “OPTIONAL” in this document are to be interpreted as described in RFC 2119 .

section.title: Credentials
section.t: Vendors MUST provision devices with credentials either during manufacturing or to let those credentials be provisioned by humans at the time when those are deployed.
Each devices MUST be provisioned with a unique credential. These credentials MUST be sufficiently strong and contain high entrophy inline with state-of-the-art crypto recommendations.
Note: An entire product family of devices MAY share the same vendor credentials for attestation purposes in addition to a unique device credential.

section.title: Firmware Update
section.t: Vendors MUST offer an automatic firmware update mechanism. A discussion about the firmware update mechanisms can be found in [[I-D.iab-iotsu-report]]. The firmware update mechanism may require consent from the user if features are changed in addition to bug fixes. To prevent widespread simultaneous failure of all instances of a particular kind of device due to a bug in a new firmware release, automatic firmware updates SHOULD be phased-in over a short time interval rather than updating all devices at once.
Devices SHOULD be configured to either poll the manufacturer's firmware update server at irregular intervals or use a push mechanism.
Firmware updates MUST be authenticated; unauthenticated updates or updates where the authentication failes MUST be rejected.

section.title: Bug Reporting
section.t: Vendors MUST provide an easy to find way for reporting of security bugs, which is free of charge.

section.title: Software Development Practices
section.t:
Vendors are encouraged to use modern software development practices, including
periodic checking of bug databases for reported security bugs associated with product periodic checking of third party-provided source code for security bugs periodic interaction with third parties where code is provided as a binary
All known security bugs MUST be fixed prior to shipping code.

section.title: Support Commitment
section.t: Vendors MUST be transparent about their commitment to supply devices with updates before selling products to their customers and what happens with those devices after the support period finishes.

section.title: Randomness
section.t: Vendors MUST include a solution for generating random numbers in their products. Randomness is an important component in security protocols and without such randomness many of today's security protocols offer weak or no security protection. The use of hardware-based random number generators SHOULD be preferred.
A discussion about randomness can be found in [[RFC 4086]].

section.title: Operating Systems Concepts
section.t: Vendors SHOULD consider using (real-time) operating systems that offer memory compartmentalization techniques. Such mechanisms reduce the impact of a software bug, such as a buffer overflow vulnerability. Operating systems, or even software running bare metal, that do not provide such a separation allow an attacker to gain access to the complete address space. While these concepts are available in hardware for a long time already they often are not utilized by real-time operating systems.
Vendors that do not make use of such features must document their design rational.

section.title: Labeling
section.t: Vendors MUST have a manufacturer, model number and hardware revision numberlegibly printed on the device. This attempts to help customers with bug reporting.
There SHOULD be a documented means of querying a device for its firmware revision number via its network interface and/or via any manual input and display.

section.title: Use of Standards
section.t:
Designing cryptographic algorithms, and security protocols is known to be difficult and error prone. We strongly RECOMMEND that vendors make use of standardized security algorithms and protocols conforming with state-of-the-art key length recommendations.
Vendors MUST provide a way for crypto agility. The concept of crypto agility is described in [[CRYPTO-AGILITY]].

section.title: Documentation
section.t: Vendors MUST offer documentation about their products so that security experts are able to assess the design choices. While such a document will not directly help end customers since they will almost always lack the expertise to judge these design decisions but they help security experts to assess liability and independent third parties to compare products without spending an unproportional amount of time.

This form of public documentation will help transparency similar to other documentation requirements found in other industries. It will also help to evolve the best practices described in this document.
